comments.commentBody: Perhaps the attention being given to the bogus Trump University and Bernie Sanders preposterous call for free college for all will at long last force a complete overhaul of higher education in this country.  The majority of colleges in this country should be shut down.  For Profit colleges must be reined in immediately!  Why isn’t it done?  One answer is surprisingly simple: if you close the college, you close the town; not unlike obsolete military bases and underutilized post offices.  Politicians lack the intelligence, integrity, fortitude and foresight to enlighten their constituencies and pursue visionary, long term alternatives to sustain their social and economic well being.  Students and their beleaguered parents are being tragically misled so that we can meet the short term goal of keeping students off the streets and providing college-related jobs in many struggling communities which have no other viable sources of income.  The vilest tragedy is not the waste of the taxpayer’s dollar.  It is the virtually inevitable shattering of the hopes and dreams of students and their families while saddling them with a lifetime of insurmountable debt that they can never repay because they have not been taught the skills to get a job which will allow them to do so.  Many public and   We must identify the real educational needs of our nation and provide the direction, support and means for existing institutions to teach the skills that meet those needs.

replies.commentBody: Question. If The New York Times has such an obvious "bias", why keep on reading it and peddling your candidate to readers who are evidently too dense to get it??? ...just asking.

The Constitution protects religion from government, and more importantly the government from religion. The Founders were aware of the destructive force of religion on European governments, and sought to protect Americans from immorality spread by religious zealots in the name of freedom. The Republican candidates all push their love of Christianity in our faces every time they open their lying mouths. None of them however care at all about peace in the world, poverty or any other humanistic values. Remember, "When Fascism comes to America, it will be wrapped in a flag and carrying a cross."

comments.commentBody:
I feel dirty just reading the New York Times anymore. Their obscene yellow slip of journalistic bias is showing.

There is a candidate who actually cares about the health, happiness, and welfare of the people, and who isn't a complete nutter. That candidate is Bernie Sanders, whom the NYT and other increasingly rightist establishment news media have chosen to ignore.

replies.commentBody: After looking at last night's Republican debate, that should be an easy one to answer.
Times may change, but people don't.  I am with Ibsen.  Thanks for bringing him back.

comments.commentBody:
“The majority is never right. Never, I tell you! That's one of these lies in society that no free and intelligent man can help rebelling against. Who are the people that make up the biggest proportion of the population -- the intelligent ones or the fools?”
― Henrik Ibsen, An Enemy of the People

replies.commentBody:
Republicans only make up 30% of the population. Certainly only a small percentage vote in primaries, and Trump gets 33% of those.

I'm as worried as you are about Trump. But I figure/hope that the country would never elect such a buffoon. Polls now show him losing to both Hillary and Bernie.

comments.commentBody:
CON'S reporter Dana Bash asked John Kasich if he thought the American people wanted an adult in the room, and he answered that he thinks they do.
.
Trump's popularity indicates they don't. Kasich is the most reasonable, rational, experienced, mature, civil, and presidential of the Republican candidates and he's doing the worst in the campaign.
.
If people don't get this figured out and quickly, Trump will get the nomination and we'll be in a world of hurt no matter how it turns out.

replies.commentBody: maybe he isn't but I am, and I share that view.
Not something to advertise.
You forgot the handicapped!  Let's say it: Trump is a brat and an imbecile.  Good luck, America!

comments.commentBody: I'm sick of the sickening Trump-bashing by the establishment.  Trump is not the "chaos candidate"  as Jeb! Bush warned; he's not a right-wing Republican either.  I think that he'll work doubly hard for the middle class and the poor once he is elected because he knows that the people that are bashing him are the problem - not him.   He will return the favor of being elected President to the People who put him there. He will be a Great President from day one of his term and the Republican congress will be forced to go along for the ride.

If every American, Mexican, Muslim and African-American hasn't already taken notice of what having Donald Trump in the White House would mean, now is the time to do so. The fact that his Presidential run has even gotten this far still continues to amaze G.O.P officials, political pundits, and everyone else with a modicum of intelligence.
His appeal to the disgruntled, (and Bernie Sanders supporters who would vote for him in a thrice over Hillary Clinton) may end up sealing the doom for the rest of the country. I have never had any reason to doubt the wisdom of Nate Cohn. But this time, I hope he is wrong. The Ides are upon us.

The Republican establishment brought this on themselves. When Trump was selling his birther nonsence, The Republicans sat quiet and smirked in the corner. Then Romney goes to Trump for his endorcement and bows and Kisses Trump. He tells the world what a great leader Trump is.  So know they have a Quagmire. How do we Stop Trump? Funny how they want to kill the Monster they created.

Barry Goldwater precisely predicted today's condition of the GOP and its cause.
"In the past couple years, I have seen many news items that referred to the Moral Majority, prolife and other religious groups as "the new right," and the "new conservatism." Well, I have spent quite a number of years carrying the flag of the old conservatism. And I can say with conviction that the religious issues of these groups have little or nothing to do with conservative or liberal politics.
The uncompromising position of these groups is a divisive element that could tear apart the very spirit of our representative system, if they gain sufficient strength."

replies.commentBody: And if Trump is repudiated by those conscience-filled delegates on the convention floor, what then?  Chicago 1968 anyone?  Dream on.

comments.commentBody: All of the talk has been about candidates gaining an x number of delegates. But those delegates are individual people with a conscience and if their conscience doesn't let them vote for Trump (I understand they are supposed to be promised to a candidate, but these times are different) there would be a revolt on the floor of the GOP's convention. This would perhaps lead to the brokered convention being discussed. It is up to the delegates to speak with one voice to repudiate Trump.

The right has clearly brought this on themselves -- it is the logical conclusion of the hate-based no-information radio and TV they've been saturating the airwaves with.

And the great recession and a clown-bus full of awful candidates and this is what you get. Trump is running as a neo-fascist. We have no idea how bad he might be if he came to power -- with fascists things usually do go from bad to worse pretty fast. He might be no worse than Berlusconi, but then again don't bet on it. (Remember that Hitler was elected.)
I'm voting for Hillary. She is the only qualified candidate in either party.

The Donald reminds me of Huey Long, a southern governor in the last century who tried to become unto his self what he thought everyone wanted, except for the guy who shot him on the steps of his Capitol.

replies.commentBody: Thanks, no.
Can we borrow your PM Trudeau?

comments.commentBody:

Spread the word
and write it in.

replies.commentBody: And Hillary's paranoia reminds me of Tricky Dick!
Longing for the much simpler days of "I am not a crook"....

Delighted that I am not the only one who is reminded of Tricky Dick when I see Hillary in debate mode. It must be the perma-scowl (without the five o'clock shadow) and the early 70s era pantsuits. Oh - and the lies.

comments.commentBody: the photo with his arms outstretched reminds me of Nixon

replies.commentBody: Wait... really?  You think Obama is a friend to the .1% but Trump is a man of the people?  Wow.

Incomplete answer.
Trump supporters are also (in part) straight out racists who see nothing wrong with dividing the country even further down those lines. But of course that won't be a problem, as long as you aren't Mexican, Muslim or African-American.
Why else would he get an endorsement from David Duke, a former Grand Wizard of the KKK. Get real.

TNC, Seems like you have bought (and regurgitated) all the lies.  The predicted "huge" tax increases from the ACA have not materialized.  The reports of the death of the economy seem premature, as the country is now at full employment after the greatest recession in eighty years (although there are still pockets, particularly in center cities that have yet to see the economic recovery).  The wage disparity does come from the 1% who give themselves bonuses for suppressing the wages and cutting the benefits of the rest of us.  And here is where I'll try to break it to you gently- Trump is the 1% (By his own modest admission, he is "really, really rich").  Obama did not hire undocumented aliens to work below prevailing wage and then not pay some of them to work on Obama Tower.  He doesn't have a union working below prevailing wage in Obama Casino with whom he is refusing to negotiate.  He didn't exchange mountains of debt for a useless degree from Obama University.  And he didn't "self finance" his campaign by loaning money to a campaign LLC to be paid back to him plus interest by his donors.  PT Barnun said "There's a sucker born every minute."  TNC, don't be one of them.

comments.commentBody: GOP brought Trump upon themselves. They have angered many Dems and Reps by their dedication to not allowing many successes for Obama regardless of the underlying reasons for that. They angered Dems and Independents and even some Rebs by trying to stop most Obama initiatives (for the good of the country) by going the opposite of whatever Obama was trying to do, even if it meant going against their ideology. Then they angered the far right by not refuting Obamacare and other initiatives, even thought votes were not there. They became the party of NO, while never offering any reasonable alternatives. They have managed to get almost everyone angry...some has rubbed off on Dems, who are unfairly taking some of the heat for not getting things done (not enough jobs - blocked by GOP). Now they have Frankenstein's monster.

replies.commentBody: The ignorant masses of the Republican Party on the street are so angry they are trying to foist a two-bit carnival huckster on the country.

Your point is correct - and Clinton had a cozy relationship with Goldman as well.
Why should we vote against our interests and give Goldman entree to the White House.

comments.commentBody:
Even as it sounds the alarm, the Republican Party has only itself to blame for this situation. First of all, Republicans proudly became the party of “no,” repeatedly opposing President Obama, but offering no real solutions themselves. They installed people like Senators Rubio and Cruz, who specialize in saying “no” – except to the donor class. Secondly, in the wake Mitt Romney’s grueling march to the nomination, they opted to change the rules, making it easier for a frontrunner to accumulate delegates. Little did they anticipate that someone like Trump would be that frontrunner.

The anti-Trump forces seem ready to plot and scheme at the convention itself if necessary. What they fail to understand is the depth of voter dissatisfaction with the Republican status quo. Voters see in Rubio a man bought and paid for by a billionaire or two. Cruz, meanwhile, is practically married to Goldman Sachs; his wife made around $1,000,000 last year alone, catering exclusively to clients who held at least $40 million with that investment bank. Faced with those sorts of choices, Republican voters choose Trump – an actual billionaire with little patience for the pieties and pretensions of the party he seems likely to lead.

replies.commentBody: Yes, this is correct. It is insanity to think that a president can resolve the "question" of allowing abortions which have been a regular occurrence over a millennium. Let's not waste time, it won't take away the regrettable need for such things.
For as along as there are men on earth, there will be abortions.  Christians or not.

comments.commentBody: The thing that the press, including NYT, seems to miss is that evangelical Christians may not want a presidential candidate who seeks to upset the delicate secular/religious balance struck by the Supreme Court.  Christians -- and for that matter any religious adherents  -- may not like abortion, gay marriage and mandatory Obamacare, but they also don't want to thrust our country into internecine warfare over these issues.  Mr. Trump says he's Christian, but unlike Cruz and Rubio, he's not promising to devote the next presidency to culture clashes that in the end no one will win.

replies.commentBody: He is ignored because he has no chance to win, neither does Cruz.

Well he telegraphs it for anyone with a memory of the Neo Con thinktank  Project for a New American Century, Dick Cheney, Paul Wolfowitz, Richard Perle.  Right there in his branded catchphrase he ends every speech with and plasters behind himsef at rallies.

comments.commentBody: It is so odd that no journalists care to investigate Rubio's deficiencies. Many of us know that his foreign policy advisers are leading neoconservatives, that he sold his soul to two billionaire Israeli-occupation-forever donors, that he knows less than nothing about foreign policy and so would be easily malleable by the neocons/Netanyahu. He wants to double the size of the military, and cancel the Iran nuclear agreement on day one (just before somehow canceling the Affordable Care Act). This is an extremely dangerous candidate, far more dangerous in US foreign policy than Trump or even Cruz would be. Why is he considered a moderate? Just because he dresses well and once supported open immigration? Does that make up for the extremism on every other policy issue?

Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell's protest of racism and bigotry in "The Party Of Lincoln" is pathetic if not laughable given their almost 50 year "Southern Strategy" of dog whistles including Reagan's "welfare queens", Bush's Willie Horton ads and Newt Gingrich's "food stamp president" description of President Obama as a few of the highlights.

The Times would do it's readers a service to feature an article revisiting George Wallace's very effective campaigns in 1968 and 1972 attracting racist low-information white working class voters using methods largely co-opted by the GOP beginning with Reagan in 1980.

replies.commentBody: Yes, we all should remember Hitler won fairly free elections twice in 1932 with roughly a third of the vote.  Then, because the extremely splintered opposition (dozens of parties) was gobsmacked by these results, it couldn't get its act together fast enough to stop the Nazis from obliterating political freedom in the blink of an eye.  FDR was smart enough and charismatic enough to know how to save the capitalist system from either communism or fascism, which were real possibilities in the US in those days.  This time it is Mr. Trump who has the charisma, not, say Ms. Clinton, who may be as smart as FDR was, but doesn't connect with masses of people in the same way.  As has been extensively reported, a recent study showed that the characteristic that Trump supporters show more than any other characteristic is a penchant for an authoritarian leader (even as they claim to want more individual freedom) who tells them right from wrong and promises to fix everything without any effort or sacrifice on their part.  Does Donald Trump not fit that description?  Beware the Ides of March!
Agree. Watch this, it's scary: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/02/29/trump-to...
You mean it wasn't GWB? or Reagan?

comments.commentBody: As a European history major in college, I was often baffled by how it was that Germans elected Adolf Hitler.   I understand it better now.  It was by appealing to the worst fears and ugliest part of our natures.  That is what Donald Trump is doing as well.   It is appallingly scary to me.  Trump represents the antithesis of what this country has tried to stand for.  Although he is the grandson of immigrants (who changed the name to make it sound less German due to anti-German sentiments), he is supporting an America which is narrow-minded and racist, xenophobic and sexist.  Wake up, America.

replies.commentBody:
How about stopping TPP? How about cutting back on the so-called, badly audited skilled worker visas- H1b, L1 and B1 visas? How about letting the market devise better pay rates when illegal immigrants are out if the picture.
My Senators have been influenced by the PACs, Clinton is bought.
Trump is independent in this part of politics and doesn't have to worry about Goldman's donations so he CAN set up a way to change this.
For all the furor, follow the money.
The politicians fighting to derail Trump have benefited big time from their association with Wall Street and K Street and now must do their masters' bidding.

comments.commentBody: I am not sure the average GOP voter out there cares if Trump says racist things or cozies up to racists. But they supposedly hate government spending and government control of business. Trump seems to be promising all these out-of-work blue-collar people jobs or help -- how? How will he force companies to bring manufacturing jobs back to U.S. rural communities? It seems like automation has cut back on the need for those jobs, and the American consumer is addicted to cheap goods and cheap food. We all relish the fruits of globalization, even though we know it has decimated many American communities and left our fellow citizens adrift and suffering. All those past candidates who talked about "job retraining" didn't produce much. How will Trump help those people who are flocking to him? Tariffs? Laws that block U.S. companies from manufacturing in cheap-labor countries?
Give it to Trump, he got his fans to get out and vote. Cruz and Rubio are now on the ropes. And once March 15th passes, they will be out of the race, too.
One can only hope.

Maybe the Republican poobahs  don't represent the it people?  Most people don't remember the days before Reagan when most republicans were moderates. I was a republican then. Now I am a democrat--but I am still a moderate. Therefore a left wing Uber liberal party doesn't suit me. I think there are many of us who wont vote for Hillary. Perhaps we could vote for Trump--an imperfect candidate (aren't they all these days?) but a moderate, I'm convinced. Get rid of these evangelicals, conservatives and Mitch McConnel types.  Most moderate people have had enough. By the way, I like Bernie, too. Perhaps I am tired of the party brass on BOTH sides shoving their tired candidates in my face. Obviously, I am not alone. #silentmajority?

replies.commentBody: Mere racist drivel. Trump's appeal has little to do with race. It has much to do with a economic issues, stifling political correctness and the intractability of the Republicans in Congress.

comments.commentBody: why is this so surprising ? -  Donald Trump is the only non-Hispanic White Male that is leading in a party that is about the non Hispanic White Male
